turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in Ralston against Robinson.
Mr. Strauss, I think you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court, the issue in this case is whether a Federal prisoner serving a sentence under the Youth Corrections Act, who commits a crime and is sentenced to a consecutive term of imprisonment as an adult, must continue to be treated as a Youth Corrections Act offender for the remainder of his Youth Corrections Act term.
In 1974, the Respondent in this case, Mr. Robinson, was convicted of second degree murder in the District of Columbia.
The maximum punishment for that offense is life imprisonment.
The Respondent was sentenced to ten years under the Federal Youth Corrections Act, or YCA.

The YCA permits a Judge as an alternative to imposing an adult sentence to commit an offender under the age of 22 to the Bureau of Prisons for a program of treatment designed to correct his antisocial tendencies and restore him to a normal, productive, and law-abiding life.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not to fit in with a group of hardened criminals.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.
There is no suggestion that Congress intended it for that reason.

Congress intended also that the YCA be modeled on the English Borstal system, and provided as one aspect of YCA treatment that YCA offenders be segregated insofar as practical from other classes of offenders.
In 1975, while he was serving his YCA sentence, the Respondent was convicted of assaulting a Federal correctional officer with a deadly weapon.

The Judge before whom he was convicted expressly declined to sentence him under the YCA, found that the Respondent would not benefit further from YCA treatment, and sentenced him as an adult to a five and a half year term of imprisonment.

The Judge specified that this sentence was to run consecutively to the YCA term, and recommended that the Respondent be moved from the youth facility where he had been being confined to a more secure institution.
Two years later, in 1977, the Respondent was again convicted of assaulting a Federal prison guard, and although he was not yet 22, he was again sentenced to an adult term of imprisonment.
This time the sentence was one year and a day.
The Judge specified that this sentence was to run consecutively to his other two sentences.
When the Respondent received his adult sentences, he acquired a dual status; although he was still serving a YCA term, he was also under an adult sentence.
At this point, the Bureau of Prisons, following an established policy for dealing with dual status offenders, began treating the Respondent in prison as an adult offender.
The effect of this was that the Respondent was given access to those treatment programs designed for adults as opposed to those programs designed for youthful offenders.
In doing this, the Bureau was exercising a power that is possessed by correctional authorities under the Borstal system, the English Borstal system, which as I said was the model for the YCA.
In that system, the authorities could transfer an offender from a youth institution to an adult prison in a case like this.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Strauss, just on that analogy, in the Borstal system they could do that even without a second conviction, couldn't they?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.
They could do it.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you take the position that the Bureau of Prisons could do that under the YCA if this man had just been a very unruly inmate, and caused a lot of trouble, but never actually was convicted of a second felony?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is not a necessary part of our argument here, because he has been convicted twice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what is your view on that question?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Our view is that the Bureau should have considerably more latitude in doing that than--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But what is your view on the question I asked you?
Does the Bureau have the power to do that without a second conviction?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --The Bureau does have the power to... Given the practicalities of the situation, the Bureau should have the power to place him in an adult institution.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You really don't need to rely on the second conviction then to sustain your position.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is our position, but we do have the second conviction in this case.

In 1978, the Respondent brought this action to challenge the Bureau's policy by filing a pro se document in the United States District Court, in which he sought to be segregated from adult offenders, and to be treated according to the provisions of the YCA.
The District Court ordered relief, ordering that Respondent be moved to an institution where he would be segregated and would receive YCA treatment.

At the time the District Court granted relief, the Respondent, because of his two adult convictions, and because he had compiled an extensive disciplinary record in prison, including several violent incidents, was in the control unit of the United States Penetentiary at Marion, Illinois.
That is the most secure unit of the most secure facility in the Federal prison system.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And as of January, this all will be moot.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right, Justice Marshall.
As of January, he begins his first adult sentence.
The Seventh Circuit affirmed the District court's order, and on our petition this Court granted certiorari.
The Respondent relies on the provisions of the YCA, which prescribe segregation and treatment for YCA offenders.

The segregation requirement, as Respondent virtually concedes, and as, in any event, this Court has said and the legislative history demonstrates beyond any reasonable doubt, was intended to allow the Bureau to insulate YCA offenders from the corrupting influence of more hardened, experienced adult offenders.
The Respondent is precisely the sort of offender from whom YCA offenders are supposed to be segregated.
He is under two adult sentences.
He has been in prison since he was 17, and his terms will not expire until he is 31.
He has committed three violent felonies, and he has an extensive disciplinary record.
This is just the sort of offender Congress had in mind when it decided that YCA offenders should, insofar as practical--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But I gather, Mr. Strauss, that there is nothing in the legislative history to show that Congress ever contemplated this situation, is there?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That's right.
In fact, it seems reasonably clear that Congress did not contemplate this situation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: On the face of the statute, it might appear that he is entitled to YCA treatment.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, the language--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: On the face of the statute it seems that way, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --It is essentially unenlightening.
We do not suggest that it supports our position directly.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It is rather explicit, it seems to me.

But in any event, in any event, I gather your argument is that we can forget what the statute says, and just in contemplation of what Congress had in mind, this is not the kind of chap who is supposed to get YCA treatment.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, when the language of the statute is essentially not addressed to this problem, and leaves us where we started, then we have to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Your argument seems to be that it would defeat the purposes of the statute as explicitly declared by Congress, if they were to put him with other young youth offenders.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That is exactly right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And there is no provision in the Federal institutions for hardened YCA people and unhardened ones.
There is only one level.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, there are different levels of security for different types of YCA offenders and types of adult offenders.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There are?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why couldn't you put this guy in that one?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, there are several problems.
One problem is that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought you only had one.
Well, excuse me.
There are different levels.
Is this by regulation or is this by the statute?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --This is not by the statute.
This is by Bureau of Prisons policy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: By regulation.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.
The statute authorizes it, but the Bureau of Prisons has established it.

One problem, Justice Marshall, to answer your question, is that in several lower Court decisions constraints have been put on the Bureau's power to place troublesome YCA offenders in maximum security institutions, and given those constraints, they have to place this sort of offender, for whom the Act is so clearly not designed, in a YCA institution--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Like a maximum security YCA institution.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --There are no maximum security YCA institutions.
There are YCA offenders in maximum security custody.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where are they?
In the regular institutions?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So in the YCA institutions you don't have any separation.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: There are YCA offenders in separate units.
Actually, this is a difficult matter to talk about, because the policy is in flux.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think you are not addressing my question.
In the same YCA institution, do you or do you not have two levels of security, in the same YCA institution?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: There are... The YCA units consist only of offenders at a single level of security in any institution.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is what I thought.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: There are YCA units within institutions, and the institution is at a security level.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The man involved here, if put in a YCA institution by a Court, would be right beside the guy that was doing just fine.
He might very well.
That's right.

We have something of a practical problem with this case, too, don't we, because if the case is argued now and the opinion doesn't come down before he begins serving his adult sentence, there will be an issue of mootness which we have traditionally dealt with by the Munsingwear case.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.
Yes.
We regret the practical problem.
We agree the proper disposition would be a Munsingwear order should the Court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So whatever this Court does, it isn't going to have much effect on this particular Respondent.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, it will only affect a couple of months of his custody, but of course, that is enough to save it from mootness, and as we explained when we asked the Court to expedite consideration of this case, it is a pressing issue for several other reasons.
There is a severe conflict in the Circuits.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I want to be sure, because I think... I want to be sure about your colloquy with Justice Marshall.
There is no such thing as a YCA institution as such.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: At this time, there is not.
There is a plan in the works for establishing two and possibly three institutions consisting exclusively of YCA offenders.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does that depend on the outcome of this case?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: No, it does not.
It depends on the outcome of separate litigation.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the budget.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: No doubt, the budget.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Strauss, may I ask you a question?
Under the Youth Corrections Act, I suppose it is possible that the youth offender will serve a longer period of time in custody than if he were an adult, for example.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is possible, right?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is right.
Under a different provision of the Act from the one under which the Respondent here is sentenced.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right, and if that is the case, and the theory of upholding that kind of a provision was that the youth offender would be getting special treatment, so there is a quid pro quo, in effect, is that not right?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is the theory that some Courts have used.
Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Then, if the Bureau of Prisons can transfer someone in the middle of a youth offender sentence to an adult facility, then you lose that quid pro quo, don't you?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, that seems to be right, Justice O'Connor.
The quick answer to that concern is that Mr. Robinson, the Respondent here, was not sentenced to a longer term than an adult could have received.
An adult could have received life imprisonment.
He was sentenced to ten years.
So, whatever those concerns are, they are not present in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But wouldn't our holding here cause major concerns in future cases if that happened to be the situation?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, that would, of course, depend on the contours of the holding.

As for the other cases, I would point out that the argument is by no means decisive, because what offenders in YCA custody are entitled to is what Congress gave them, and if we can establish that Congress did not intend that this program would survive beyond the point where is served any purpose, then it can't be said that they are being denied or deprived of something that Congress intended them to have.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I follow up with that?

Is it your view that the second trial judge at the time of the second offense could have imposed a concurrent sentence instead of a consecutive sentence, which would then have authorized the Bureau to treat him as an adult rather than a YCA offender?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Yes, if the second judge... you mean the judge who sentenced him to his first adult sentence?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: If he had imposed a concurrent sentence, I would think there would be no question.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Couldn't the Department of Justice pretty much take care of the problem by asking for concurrent sentences whenever a YCA offender commits another felony?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, it could.
Of course, that actually points out a paradox in the situation, that an offender whose crime was not sufficiently serious--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It can't get the benefit of the longer YCA sentence that Justice O'Connor adverted to it it did that, of course.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That's right.
Also, he wouldn't get the benefit--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What he wants to do is get the benefit of the length of the YCA sentence but not the quid pro quo.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, he wants to impose a consecutive sentence essentially, the adult sentence to go on top of it.
The paradox is that consecutive sentences ordinarily denote a more serious offense, and the lower Court's decision--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So they want the additional time, and they also want to change the character of the first sentence.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, the Judge decided the additional time was necessary, and that makes it necessary also to change the character of the first sentence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, it doesn't make it necessary.
Under the Department's policy it is desirable to change the character of the first sentence.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, that's right.
It is not necessary.
It is not something we are required to do.
In our view, it is necessary in order to maintain Congress' intention in enacting the statute.

The other point about the segregation requirement is that, as Justice Rehnquist pointed out, and as Justice Blackmun, in three months' time, the Respondent will begin his adult sentence, and at that time it is beyond dispute that he will be an adult offender, and no one would contend that at that time he can claim a right to be segregated from adults or placed as a YCA offender, but there is no basis for thinking that he is somehow less of a corrupting influence now than he will be three months from now, or that he is more fit to be placed with YCA offenders now than he will be in three months.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, any decision the Court is going to make is going to apply to someone who might have nine years left, or a longer period.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is right, but I think the same point still holds, that there is no basis for believing that at the earlier point, after he has committed a crime and sentenced as an adult, that somehow he will not become a corrupting influence until that sentence begins to run.

The other provision of the YCA on which the Respondent relies is the treatment provision, and again, the Courts below have applied this provision to the kind of offenders for whom Congress did not intend it.

YCA treatment in Congress' view was designed, as Justice Rehnquist suggested in an earlier question, to return offenders to productive lives in the community, and to that end an integral part of the treatment Congress envisioned was a gradual phased, supervised reintegration of an offender into society.
At the end of his YCA term however, the Respondent, of course, will not be returned to a productive life in society.
Instead, he will begin two adult prison terms, and for that same reason it will be impossible gradually to reintegrate him into society.
So, an integral part of YCA treatment as Congress saw it will not be capable of being afforded to this Respondent.

Nothing in the Act suggests that YCA treatment is preparation for a life in prison, and nothing in the Act suggests that the custodial phase of YCA treatment followed by an adult prison term will do anyone any good, society or the offender.

It is at least plausible that a custodial treatment program designed to culminate in an offender's return to society when followed not by a return to society but by an adult prison sentence will do even the offender more harm than good.
So, if anything, it thwarts Congress' intention to attempt to provide Respondent with YCA treatment.
Certainly, there is no basis in the YCA for requiring the Bureau of Prisons to provide treatment to an offender such as this.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I think you have answered this, but there would be no question if either one of these two Judges had said YCA, would there?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: If the Judge had imposed YCA sentences, he would be a YCA offender.
That is right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And there would be no problem.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: He would still be a YCA offender.
There would be no basis for claiming he is an adult offender.

I would point out that, as Justice Stevens suggested earlier, if his prison record were very bad, it might be necessary to take some steps that would require confining him in conditions comparable to those of an adult offender, but the Bureau would still regard him as a YCA offender.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It is up to the Judge, not to the Department of Justice.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: To decide whether someone is a YCA offender or an adult offender.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is right, although the treatment conditions have to be in the control of the Bureau, and the confinement conditions more generally.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I still don't understand why it isn't sufficient to achieve the Department's end to just leave it to the Bureau if he is a youth offender to deal with him as an adult, or confine him as an adult, or confine him like they would an adult, if he gets out of hand.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, it may be sufficient if we could do that.
One problem with that is that constraints have been put on the Bureau by the lower Courts.
The other problem--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So you really think what this case is really about is the validity of the existing policy of the Bureau.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, the case is about the validity of the existing policy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I mean, whether they may confine a youth offender as an adult if he gets out of hand.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: The obstacles that have been put in the way of implementation of that policy give this case its practical importance.
Our view is that the proper interpretation of the statute remains, that Congress did not intend YCA treatment for someone who is going off to an adult--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Strauss, are you suggesting to my brother White that without a second conviction, just because of misbehavior, the policy of the Department would permit their treating him as an adult, even though he had been sentenced as a youth offender?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --There may be some circumstances, in our view, under which a YCA offender is such a problem, the only practical way to deal with him is to place him in an adult penitentiary.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that is the Bureau's presently published policy, isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is the Bureau's present policy, and it is one that--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, its validity is not involved in this case.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That's right.
Its validity is not necessarily involved in this case, because he would--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not necessarily.
It is not involved.
You put in another word.
You put in another word, not necessarily.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, if the Court were to hold that the Bureau has complete discretion to place an unruly offender in adult conditions whether or not he has a YCA... has an adult sentence, then a--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, if we were to do that, we would be answering a question that this case doesn't present.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Ordinarily, isn't it the case that if you take a person 23 years old off the street and try him for a crime and the Judge sentences him to 20 years, he begins serving that sentence as soon as the Trial Judge directs, or as soon as his appeals are exhausted?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is my understanding.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And here, of course, he begins serving the adult sentence after the YCA sentence expires.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If there was a ten-year YCA sentence, as there was here in 1974, and say in the first trial, the first offense was in 1975, and the Trial Judge gave him one year, as he did the last time, it is your view that that one-year adult sentence would entitle the Bureau to give him ten years of adult treatment, isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That one-year adult sentence, in our view, would make him an adult offender, yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And then the whole ten-year sentence could be treated as an adult sentence.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Strauss, would the government regard an affirmance here as invalidating the policy?
The present policy.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: The policy of treating YCA offenders with adult convictions as--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --I assume.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The present policy you told us, without regard to an adult conviction, that they can treat him as an adult if he gets too far out of hand.
I thought you just told me that.
That is the policy.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: The policy of treating a straight YCA--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: A YCA offender may be treated as an adult if he gets too far out of hand.
That is the present Bureau policy, isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That's right, essentially.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And if we affirm here, are you suggesting that that would invalidate that policy?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, that would be a difficult question.
It would depend on the nature of the affirmance.
It would be difficult--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I am just talking about an affirmance.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, this offender has two adult sentences for serious crimes in prison.
It is hard to see how someone could be more unruly than that.
So to that extent it would be a problem.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is true, but you think an affirmance here would prevent the Bureau under its present policy from confining him as an adult?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Again--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: If we affirmed.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Simply, if you simply entered an order of affirmance, I suppose it would be possible to carry out the other policy, but as I said, it is difficult to see how this offender can be... can assert a right to continue the YCA treatment unless any unruly YCA offender could.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The argument is, that is what the Act says.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, in our view, that is not what the Act says or intends.
I should also point out that the Bureau's policy that we have been talking about of placing unruly YCA offenders in adult conditions applies only to segregation.
The YCA forms of treatment, the characteristic forms of education and counseling made available to youths would still be available to them.

Essentially the problem is that he would have to be put in some place like the control unit at Marion, where he is under very close supervision all the time, and as a practical matter in those conditions we cannot talk of segregation from adult offenders.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Strauss, if you know the policy, or if you know the background, has the Bureau of Prisons had any occasion to take an unruly youth offender who is in custody, who is thought to be subject to some emotional problems, and sent him off to a Federal psychiatric institution for analysis and treatment?
Have they done that, do you know?
If you know?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: I would suspect they have.
I don't know of any particular cases, but I would suspect it has been done.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is common, or at least it is not uncommon with respect to other prisoners in other Federal institutions, isn't it?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: No, it is common, and in fact my understanding is that at the Federal psychiatric prison institution at Butner, there are YCA offenders.
That is a mixed institution specializing in psychiatric treatment.
The Respondent also happens to be there, but he is there as an adult.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course, Burner is a very special institution.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That is right.
It specializes in psychiatric treatment.
If there are no further questions, I will save the rest of my time.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Solovy?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the Court, I would like first to address Justice Blackmun's question of mootness, because Mr. Robinson and I sort of feel like the baseball player who came up from the minors to the big leagues, and then a baseball strike is called, and Mr. Robinson having struggled this long to get his YCA-mandated treatment as directed by Congress, I hate to see him lose it.
Number one, the mootness argument presumes that this Court will not act expeditiously.
I will not indulge in that presumption.
But if one were to indulge that presumption, I would like to point out that in January 1982, Mr. Robinson will only be conditionally released from this YCA sentence.
At that point he will start serving his adult sentence, and should he be paroled within two years, he would still be subject to the YCA sentence and could be called back into the YCA system.
Now, a lot of questions have been asked by the Court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You mean in a sense for what would amount to violations of parole, the equivalent of parole.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --That is correct, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, what do you have to say about the proposition, laying aside the statute for just a moment, that this man is now demonstrably on this record precisely the kind of person that Congress said should not be mixed in with youth offenders?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Quite to the contrary, with all respect, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What do these two convictions mean?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: All right.

Well, let's take... the government says that Mr. Robinson is a hardened criminal, and he must be kept in the most maximum confinement possible, namely Marion, but yet when Mr. Robinson wound his way up to the Seventh Circuit, the Bureau of Prisons started thinking about its obligations, and they transferred him to the Memphis facility, which is a minimum... a medium security, and then to Butner, which is an administrative facility.

Now, at Butner we lodged with the Court his current report, where they say he requires a minimum of supervision, his attitude is positive, he interacts well, he does his job well, he has completed courses, and that is what Congress wanted to do when they passed the YCA.
Under the YCA, a person could get a 20-year sentence.
That means that the Trial Judge thinks that this person is a hard core case.
He takes a long time to be rehabilitated.
The whole purpose--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What would you say if a man was up for youth correction, YCA treatment, and the record showed he had three felony convictions for violent crimes.
Do you think he would be a good subject?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --That, Justice Marshall, of course, is what Congress gave to the Trial Court.
Each time that that defendant came before the Trial Judge, so long as he--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I am not talking about this man.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Yes, I am talking about any person--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I am talking about a man who is brought before a Court, and this is his third conviction for violent felony.
Do you think the Court would be obliged to give him YCA treatment?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Oh, no, the Court is never under--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: To the contrary.
You would think he was not, wouldn't you?
Now, wouldn't you?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Justice Marshall, this Court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I say three violent felonies.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --This Court has mandated the answer in Dorszynski.
So long as the person is under the age of 22, the Trial Judge must make a specific no benefit finding.
You take, for example--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I am saying he makes the finding.
Which finding do you think he would make?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Well, if I were the Trial Judge, I would make the finding of no benefit.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And then I am going to ask you what is the significance of this case.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: There is a world of difference, because Mr. Robinson was judged by the Trial Court in this case to require ten years of rehabilitative treatment to straighten himself out, and I have to back away from the question that when you read the government's brief, the Court and I, until I start reading the cases, are sitting in a never-never land.
The Bureau of Prisons says, listen to our expertise, and it is impractical to mix these people together, but this system doesn't exist.
There is no YCA treatment.
There is no YCA system.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, in this case, you are not attacking the action of the Judges under later convictions.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Not at all, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: They sentenced him as an adult.
You don't complain about that.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Not at all, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: All you complain about... and the Judge himself didn't attempt to terminate his prior youth condition.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: I couldn't agree with that more.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And it is the Bureau of Prisons that said, because he has been convicted as an adult, we will terminate, treat him as an adult.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: That is exactly the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You are not suggesting that any later Judge is bound to sentence him for a later felony as a youth offender?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Not at all.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is the longest sentence that you are aware of under the Youth Corrections Act?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Twenty-five years under the YCA.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How many sentences over ten years under the YCA are made, do you know?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: The government sets it forth in its brief, and there are quite a number of them.
I don't remember the exact figures, but there are quite a number of long--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But percentagewise, it is a small percentage of cases, is it not?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Percentagewise, I would say the long sentences are about 15 to 20 percent, and of course the answer that Congress gave to these difficult prisoners, and Congress envisioned this, is found right in the statute, at Section 5011.
It says
"Classes of committed youth offenders shall be segregated according to their needs of treatment. "

So Congress knew that when you gave a youth offender 20, 25 years' worth correction sentence that there might be problems, and it said that you could house those youth offenders according to their needs for treatment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Like sending them to Marion.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: No, you can't send them to Marion--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --because Marion is a penitentiary, and Marion does not afford what Congress mandated should be afforded, which was rehabilitative treatment.
Now, the Bureau of Prisons says that the Youth Corrections Act is passe, and therefore we won't enforce it.
The Bureau of Prisons likes to mix the adult offenders with the youthful offenders, and they think that prevents violence, but that is exactly contrary to what Congress said.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Has the Bureau ever made any announcement of any such policy, or is that your inference?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: That is the direct testimony of the Bureau of Prisons in Watts versus Hadden, Bell versus Johnson, Brown versus Carlson, and as they say, that the Bureau of Prisons are much more direct in their testimony in the litigation than they are in the briefs filed with the Court.
In Watts versus Hadden, the District Judge held as follows, and this is 469 Federal Supplement 234.
I think this is a rather astounding statement.

There is an incredible irony in reading the Supreme Court's careful articulation of the policy, purposes, and procedures of the YCA in the directions given to sentencing Judges in Dorszynski with the knowledge that the entire system therein simply does not exist.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that is not the only incredible irony in this case, is it?
In a sense, you are urging that your client be continued to be confined under the sentence, whereas the government is urging that he be released from that sentence and start serving another sentence.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: I agree, Justice Rehnquist, that that is a complete irony, and that when people come before the Courts, they do not want to be sentenced under the Youth Corrections Act, because the Youth Corrections Act is not a picnic.
It gives them a longer sentence than they might normally get, and it gives them in many ways different types of treatment.
This was not supposed to be a picnic.
The Borstal system was hard work.
Now, they want to take... What the government, though, has done, Justice Rehnquist, is try to put Mr. Robinson in a penal never-never land.
Bear in mind that one year after his ten-year YCA sentence he got a consecutive adult sentence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: For doing what?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: For assaulting a prison guard.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does that seem unreasonable to you?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: No, the sentence doesn't seem unreasonable.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose the government paroles him from the YCA Act today.
Is this case moot?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Yes, except for the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He will stay right where he is, won't he?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Except for the possibility--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And you couldn't say a mumbling word.
Right?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Well, except... No, that isn't correct, because there are cases like that, Mickless, for example, Mickless versus United States, because they could then parole him the next day from the adult sentence, and since he would still be subject to being called back for a parole violation, I think the Court would have the right to render a decision as to the conditions of confinement.
But meanwhile, Justice Marshall, they haven't paroled him, and he is still there, and he is still in the wrong place, and they are still not giving him treatment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Solovy, on your initial point, I want to be sure I understood you.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You contend that because of the two-year parole at the end of his eight-year time in custody, this case will not be moot next January.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Technically, because there is a possibility of the other sentences being paroled--

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --within the two-year period.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: That is correct, but I want to make sure that the Court understands my position.
I am not quarreling with the legality of the second... of the first consecutive sentence.
The irony is that the second consecutive sentence is an illegal sentence, as this Court determined in Dorszynski, because there was no no benefit finding.
The government's position would result in strange anomalies.
Take, for example, a misdemeanor who could only get a six-month sentence.
He gets an indeterminate YCA sentence.
That means he is there for a potential four to six years.
He then gets in trouble, and he gets a one-year consecutive adult sentence.
That means he is going to end up serving five to seven years for an offense that if he were sentenced as an adult he could only be imprisoned six months, and that would be an anomalous result.
Under the Congressional scheme, it doesn't matter what pattern of sentences occur.
If a youth at the age of 18 commits a robbery and gets a one-year adult sentence, then gets in trouble again before the age of 22, he can get a YCA sentence.
This Court has mandated that a Judge make a no benefit finding.
But the question of what the Bureau of Prisons could do, whether they could yank a man in and out of his status as a YCA offender, Mr. Strauss referred to the Borstal system.
Well, the Borstal system was plainly explained to Congress, including the power to take a person from a youth facility and put him in a penal institution.
Congress did not adopt that suggestion.
They explicitly left it out.
When the initial Act was proposed in 1943, the American Law Institute proposed that the Bureau of Prisons be given the authority to determine YCA status.
All the Judges in America screamed about that.
That was rejected.
Then they proposed that the Judges and the Bureau of Prisons share these powers.
And what you had was a system in which only the Trial Court could impose a YCA sentence.
Now, bear in mind, in Dorszynski, this Court held that that determination of the Trial Judge is not reviewable by this Court.
Now, what the Bureau of Prisons is saying is that either they can countermand the judgment of the initial Trial Judge or that the second Trial Judge could do that.

Now, if this Court could not review a YCA sentence, then certainly the Bureau of Prisons could not do it, nor could the second Trial Judge, nor did the second Trial Judge in this case intend or pretend to countermand the Youth Corrections sentence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I suppose your position would be the same if the sentence were concurrent.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: No, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Why not?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: That is a good question.
I am not surprised you asked.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I have been waiting for you to get to it.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Well, that is because it is probably one of the most difficult questions in the case, and we have agonized over what the correct answer is, and correct not in the manner of espousing our position but intellectually and legally correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The question is, the question in this case is whether the later conviction automatically terminates the youth sentence, wholly aside from any discretion of the Bureau of Prisons.
That is the question I want an answer to.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Exactly.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Does it automatically terminate it when there is a concurrent sentence?
Or does it give some discretion to the Bureau to do it?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: The Bureau can have no discretion, and bear in mind when I give this answer, and I may be sailing away the rights of some poor indigent someplace--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But not yours.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Not mine.
I don't represent him.
We believe that in this case the concurrent sentence would take precedence over the Youth Corrections sentence, because otherwise you would be having the discretion of two Trial Judges in conflict.
When the Trial Judge gives a YCA and the second Judge gives a consecutive sentence, there is no tension whatsoever.
The first Judge in effect is deferring to the discretion... the second Judge defers to the discretion of the initial Judge.
But when you have a concurrent--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, there is a conflict in the sense that in order to sentence him as an adult, he has to make a no benefit finding, which is contrary to what the first Judge found.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Under different circumstances for a different time and a different--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I know, but he nevertheless says at this very moment he will not benefit from being treated as a youth, and yet your argument is that he must be treated as a youth.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Justice White, I don't think those sentences are in conflict, because his no benefit finding takes effect only upon the expiration of the youth offender sentence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that is your argument.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Well, that is the clear--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You go ahead on your concurrent sentence--

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --All right, but that is the clear answer under the Congressional Act.

However, as to the concurrent sentence, now you have two Courts of equal jurisdiction, and the second Court says, for this offense, I wish to impose a concurrent adult sentence Now, I might point out the Bureau--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --And he says no benefit.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --No benefit.

The Bureau of Prisons, according to their statistics, they say they have in the youth corrections facilities 175 persons who have consecutive and concurrent sentences so although the Bureau of Prisons... it doesn't make any difference to them because they mix adult and youth offenders up all together, so it makes no difference, but they treat them as a youth offender.

I think the answer is that that person can be immediately incarcerated as an adult offender, because the second Judge has exercised his discretion that this person should be immediately incarcerated as an adult, and I think the question is not without its difficulty, because the first Judge made a determination that the offender would benefit, but the second Judge says no.
They are both Judges of concurrent jurisdiction.
The first Judge cannot veto the power of the second Judge; as in this case, the second Judge could not countermand the sentence of the first Judge.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, he didn't even try to.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: He didn't, Justice White.
That is exactly correct.
The government quotes in its brief the language that he would not benefit further, but they omit the rest of it in which he says,
"and I decline to sentence him under the Act. "
which is exactly what he was required to do under Dorszynski.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Let me give you an easier one.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Yes, I wish you would, Justice Marshall.
You have been giving me awful hard ones.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose this man had been acquitted originally, and then knifed somebody.
Where would he go?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Well, he would go back before the sentencing Judge and that sentencing Judge under Dorszynski would exercise his discretion--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: No, he was acquitted.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --No, but I mean, under the second--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He was acquitted--

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --and he knifed somebody.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: He would go to an adult jail, wouldn't he?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Depending... if he were under 22, the Trial Judge is mandated by law and by this Court's decision--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --to make a no benefit finding.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And if he found that he was entitled to adult treatment, where would he go?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: He would go to an adult--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So the only difference here that is instead of being acquitted, he was convicted.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --The difference is, Justice Marshall--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is that right?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --that the first Judge made a judicial determination that Mr. Robinson would benefit from treatment under the Youth Corrections Act for a ten-year period.
No other Court--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Regardless of how many crimes he committed?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Well, the theory of--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Suppose he shot 18 people in six days?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Well, then I assume they would electrocute him, you know, fairly, promptly, but the theory of the Youth Corrections Act, and Mr.--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Could they do that under your theory?
Could they electrocute him under your theory?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Well, if he keeps shooting people, either... it depends upon your theory of penology.
I might veer more towards the Bureau of Prisons in that case, but--
0 [Generallaughter.]

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought you would.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Well, even lawyers like some protection.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What would happen... Suppose a Youth Corrections Act, as it was here, was pronounced, sentence was pronounced, and then the Judge said, however, I am going to put you on probation.
That will be hanging over you.
And then he goes out and commits a murder or something else.
Do you think the Youth Corrections Act sentence must be served first before the second conviction, sentence must be served?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Well, I think that is a situation that could quite frequently happen, and I think that the Judges normally in those situations will determine whether under the second offense the Judge is going to sentence him as an adult, and whether--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I am assuming that the second sentence then for murder--

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Is as an adult?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --is as an adult.
Is the Youth Corrections Act sentence going to be a barrier?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Normally, the Trial Court Judges exercise good sense, so if he has a second Judge who has given this gentleman, let's say, ten years, and as as an adult, he would not reinstitute the Youth Act sentence.

If he did, then he would have to determine which really was in progress, and I guess the answer might be that he might have to serve his Youth Corrections Act sentence, but of course, in this case, Mr. Robinson--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think that is what Congress had in mind in this Act?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --What Congress had in mind, it is very clear that if someone had the time, as I had, to read the Act and the legislative history from beginning to end, what Congress had in mind was that there was going to be a big surge of youth coming back from the war, because this Act started being considered in the early forties, and because it got tied up with an adult indeterminate sentence that the Trial Judges didn't like, it got kicked off to 1949, and they said that the percentage of crime committed by youth far exceeded their percentage of the total population, so that what Congress was trying to do was to stop hard core criminals, and we are penalizing Mr. Robinson in a way.
We are saying he is a hardened criminal, and a failure of the system, when the system really didn't exist.

Now, when he finally gets to Butner a year ago, and they finally give him the treatment that Judge Moultry said in 1974 that he should get, which was intensive individual therapy, he has reacted wonderfully.
He has completed courses in real estate, basic math.
He is a member of the band.
He does his job.
He interacts positively.
That is what Congress wanted to do.
They wanted to take the youth of America and save them from being repeater criminals.
This wasn't, as they said, a molly-coddling feel sorry for the underprivileged.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But any time a Judge, when he finds a youth offender is convicted of another crime, any time a Judge goes to sentence, if he thinks the status of the youth offender should be terminated and he should start serving an adult sentence, he can affect that by just sentencing him concurrently.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Exactly, Justice White.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And so that option is always available in such cases like this.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you know if the government asked the Judge to do that in this case?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: We, unfortunately, of course, were not appointed until we got to the Seventh--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Of course, the government's position is that you should say that automatically the youth offender status ends with the second conviction--

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --and wouldn't want to leave it just to the Judge.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: That is correct, but--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But the Judge could control it.
You agree with that?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Yes, no question, Justice White, that if he wanted to terminate a Youth Corrections Act sentence, the second Judge would enter a concurrent sentence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Is a YCA defendant entitled to the good time credits and the two-thirds maximum?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: None whatsoever, Justice Rehnquist.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So those are strictly for adult offenders?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Poor Mr. Robinson, as I say, at the end of the first year of his ten-year YCA sentence, he gets this adult sentence.
The Bureau of Prisons says, it is all over, Mr. Robinson.
No more Youth Corrections treatment, which you never got in the first place, but you are not going to get it.

And you are going to... they concede his YCA sentence is going, so therefore you will serve your full eight years before you get your conditional discharge, but as for your adult sentence, you get no credit whatsoever, and that is why the government and the Bureau of Prisons is so nervous about this case, because really you cannot say that it makes penological sense to keep Mr. Robinson incarcerated for eight years under the Youth Corrections Act and not give him the treatment that Congress mandated, and at the same time house him in Marion as an adult offender with the hardest of criminals in the nation, and say, you don't get your good time credits, you don't get your time off, nothing.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But as soon as he starts serving his adult sentence, he will receive those.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: No, not retroactively.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Not retroactively, but--

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: He won't start receiving them until January of 1982.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --Which will be the date he commences his adult sentence.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you think the Judges across the country are aware of the fact that a concurrent sentence will terminate the youth offender sentence?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: I think the Trial Judges are aware of that.

What they are not aware of, Justice White, is that the Judge found in Watts versus Hadden that the Youth Corrections Act is a myth, and that this system does not exist, because if you ask the Trial Court Judges what is going to happen to their youth offenders when they are sent to the facility, they think they will be segregated from adult offenders, they think that they will receive rehabilitative treatment.
They don't think they are going to be mixed with adult offenders who are going to enforce peace and quiet, because that isn't the intention of the Judges.

And I am surprised that the Bureau of Prisons, with the state of litigation that is going on, in Brown versus Carlson, Watts versus Hadden, Johnson versus Bell, where they are being told continuously to bring your performance within the Congressional mandate... I mean, it is 32 years later... that they would have the temerity to bring this case before the Court and say, defer to our expertise, and it would be impractical to operate the Act as Congress has mandated, when they have never tried.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the cases you have referred to are not from this Court, are they?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: No, but Dorszynzki--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Right.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --mandates segregation, rehabilitation.
It is all set out in this Court's opinion.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And it also makes the finding on review.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You still keep talking about poor Mr. Robinson, and all he did was stab a prison guard.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: But poor Mr. Robinson is someone--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Poor Mr. Robinson wants youth treatment.
Isn't that rather adult action to stab a guard?

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Justice Marshall, his first offense could not have been more adult.
It was a murder committed in the course of a robbery.
I don't think that any human being should be written off.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I just object to your using the word "poor".

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: All right.
Well, let us say--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I mean, don't make me cry about it.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: --Let us say that it is my position that Congress has mandated, whatever adjective we ascribe to Mr. Robinson, that he was to receive certain treatment, and that was rehabilitation and correction so that he would not be a threat to society.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that comes under the Act of Congress.

turn.speaker: jerold_s_solovy
turn.label: Mr. Jerold S. Solovy
turn.text: Yes, it comes under the Act of Congress.

We feel that if the government does not like the way this Act operates, if they want to run the Youth Corrections Act the way they want to run it as against the way Congress said it should be run, if they think that it is proper to mix adult offenders with youthful offenders, then we believe that that question should be put before Congress, and it should not be put before this Court, as this Court stated in Dorszynski.

If the Court should hold that this second sentence somehow revoked Mr. Robinson's youth offender status, then, as we set forth in our brief, you have serious constitutional issues of equal protection, double jeopardy, and due process.
We do not believe that the Act has to be interpreted in a manner which raises those issues.

We believe that the Seventh Circuit was clearly correct that the Third Circuit, which had issued these wonderful decisions in this area up to Thompson versus Carlson, was incorrect in its ultimate premise.
In Thompson versus Carlson, the Third Circuit clearly said to the Bureau of Prisons, you cannot unilaterally revoke this man's status.
You do not have it within your power.
As much as the Bureau of Prisons would like to have that power, they do not have it.
The Courts have uniformly held that, other than the Fourth Circuit's decision in Outing.

That is the only decision, and an early decision in Abernathy, which I do not think adequately addressed the issues, but all the other Courts have said, including Thompson versus Carlson, you do not have that power.

Thompson versus Carlson said, though, that the second Judge in imposing the sentence terminated the first youth corrections sentence, and we believe the Seventh Circuit was clearly correct in holding that that was not the effect of the second sentence.

Indeed, the consecutive adult sentence may have been imposed in Mr. Robinson's case, as the Seventh Circuit pointed out, precisely because he was serving then a youth corrections sentence, and the Court might have imposed a youth corrections sentence otherwise.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you have anything further, Mr. Strauss?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, one or two points.

Justice White, the reason that the Judge's sentencing an offender to a concurrent adult sentence doesn't solve the problem is, of course, the Judge might think, as he evidently did in this case, that the offense was sufficiently serious that the additional punishment of a consecutive sentence was necessary.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I understand.
You would rather have an automatic rule than have to convince the Judge.
I can understand that.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, the Judge in this case didn't take any convincing.
He thought a consecutive sentence... well, we don't know if he took convincing or not, but in any event he thought a consecutive sentence was necessary.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I know, but if a concurrent sentence automatically terminates a youth offender, all a Judge has to say is, he could say, ten years as an adult, and the sentence to begin immediately, the youth offender status is terminated.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, the Judge could--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is equivalent to a concurrent sentence.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That's right.
Of course, that would prohibit the Judge from sentencing a consecutive sentence, a consecutive maximum sentence under the--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I agree with you.
But in this case, exactly what did the Judge say?
Your position is that you want an automatic rule to prevent the Judge from putting on a consecutive sentence.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --We think the Judge puts on a consecutive sentence, that it would be grossly--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That the sentence should start right now.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --It should permit the Bureau not to have to treat him as a YCA offender anymore, now that YCA treatment is inappropriate for him.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Exactly what did the second Judge say with respect, if anything, to no benefit?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: He said that the offender will not benefit any further under the provisions of the YCA, and sentenced him to an adult term, and also recommended that the offender be transferred from the Federal Youth Center where he had been confined to a more secure institution.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What page is that?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: We paraphrased at Page 6 of our, brief.
It is also in the judgment and commitment order which we have lodged with the Court.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, that is just practically the same as saying, I hereby terminate the--

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, we don't rely on the Judge's statements.
What we rely on is the fact that an adult sentence was imposed, and under the Act it now makes no sense to--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --You want an automatic rule.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --as a YCA offender.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May I ask why you don't rely on the Judge's statement?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Well, we think even if the Judge hadn't made the statements that it would make no sense to take an offender who is an adult offender in the contemplation of the YCA and continue to treat him as if he were a YCA offender.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: So you want the authority to be put in the Bureau of Prisons--

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: We think--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: --to revoke the YCA status?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --No, it is not... to treat him as an adult offender.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Do you or don't you?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: We do want the Bureau to be able to say in cases like this, we are going to treat this person as an adult.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Where do they get that authority to overrule a Judge?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: I think that is a misconception that the Respondent has been repeating.
This isn't a matter of--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, isn't it true?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --Well, it is not a matter of revoking or overruling or countermanding a sentence.
The question is, what is the sentence.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, the Judge says Youth Corrections Act.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And the Bureau of Prisons says no more.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: After the second adult--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That isn't counteracted?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --That is right, because the question is, what does the Youth Corrections Act--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, where do you get that authority?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --The authority is already implicit in the Youth Corrections Act sentence.
It is sour view that Congress never intended a Youth Corrections Act sentence to be so inalienable that even--

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did the Judges know that?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: --The first sentencing Judge may very well have known that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: May.
Do they?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: We just don't know what the first sentencing Judge thought.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, where does the Bureau of Prisons get the right to overrule a Federal District Judge?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: The Bureau of Prisons is not overruling a Federal District Judge.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: It is just changing it.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: It is not even changing it.
The Federal District Judge gave him a YCA sentence.
Our problem is, what does that entail?
Specifically, does it entail continuing to treat him as a YCA offender when it makes no sense, and our view is, it does not entail that.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What you are saying, in effect, is that the second sentencing Judge is the one who has revoked or taken the action which terminates the YCA sentence.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: We think the second sentencing Judge's decision was what made it no longer appropriate to treat him as a YCA offender.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I thought you abandoned that.

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: His decision to sentence him as an adult.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, did you abandon it or not?

turn.speaker: david_a_strauss
turn.label: Mr. David A. Strauss
turn.text: Did I abandon what, Justice Marshall?

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Relying on the Judge's action.
